docs.lead_paragraph: A woman who agreed to be a surrogate mother for a childless couple is pregnant with quintuplets, all boys, and has decided not to accept the $15,000 she expected from the parents, given the expense they now face. The woman, Teresa Anderson, who has four children of her own, had thought that being a surrogate for Luisa Gonzalez and her husband, Enrique Moreno, would be equally simple. ''But it's really five times the swelling, five times the mood swings,'' Ms. Anderson told The Arizona Republic.
docs.abstract: Teresa Anderson, Phoenix mother of four who agreed to be surrogate mother for childless couple, is pregnant with quintuplets; says she will not accept $15,000 in expenses because of expenses that Luisa Gonzalez and Enrique Moreno now face (S)
docs.snippet: A surrogate mother for a childless couple in Arizona is pregnant with quintuplets, all boys, and has decided not to accept any money from the parents.

docs.lead_paragraph: Britney Expects The gossips were right. Britney Spears, left, is pregnant. In a posting on her Web site, Ms. Spears, 23, who married the dancer Kevin Federline in September, confirmed what Britney watchers have been saying: ''The time has finally come to share our wonderful news that we are expecting our first child together.'' No other details were announced, but Reuters noted that the couple recently signed a deal to star in a reality series that will document their courtship and wedding and now, presumably, Ms. Spears' pregnancy. The first episode is expected to be broadcast before the end of next month. Pavarotti Regrets The tenor Luciano Pavarotti, below, who underwent neck surgery last month to repair two vertebrae, has rescheduled two concerts in England, the BBC reported. A performance that was to take place on June 11 in Reading has been postponed until July 1, and a concert planned for July 9 at Chatsworth House in Derbyshire has been delayed until July 8, 2006. Mr. Pavarotti is, however, in Kiev, Ukraine, as part of a farewell tour. His spokeswoman, Terri Robson, said the surgery at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York was ''routine and regular.'' She added, ''His doctors reported that he recovered very quickly from his operation and have now advised that the second and final stage of this procedure must take place at the beginning of June 2005.'' More Honors Merv Griffin, below, whose creations include ''Jeopardy!'' and ''Wheel of Fortune,'' will be honored by the Museum of Television & Radio at its gala at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on May 26. Hitler in Israel The Oscar-nominated German film that depicts that portrays Hitler as a diabolical leader with a human side is to be released in Israel after it was overwhelmingly approved by a test audience last week, Reuters reported. The film ''The Downfall'' (''Der Untergang''), starring Bruno Ganz, was picked up for distribution by Nurit Shani, owner of the Lev theater chain. She said 91 percent of the viewers at a test screening approved it. Footnotes Willie Nelson will be joined by Bob Dylan when he returns to Fort Worth for his annual Fourth of July picnic performance, The Associated Press reported. ''Dame Edna: Back With a Vengeance,'' starring Barry Humphries as the self-proclaimed gigastar, will end its run at the Music Box Theater on May 1 after 17 previews and 163 regular performances.
docs.abstract: Arts, Briefly column; Britney Spears confirms, on her Web site, that she is pregnant; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: PETREK-Jeanne. The staff of the Evelyn H. Lauder Breast Center and the members of the Breast Diseases Management Team at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center mourn with the deepest sadness the sudden, tragic loss of our beloved colleague and friend Jeanne A. Petrek. Her presence in our lives was, and remains, a constant reminder of the highest aspirations of medicine, a calling to restore and preserve health in spirit as well as body. She was not only a superb surgeon who helped refine the current management of breast disease, but she was a tireless advocate for the quality of life of breast cancer patients, a leading researcher in topics such as lymphedema after breast surgery, pregnancy-associated breast cancer, and the preservation of fertility after treatment. Despite her international renown, she made every patient feel that she was the most important person in the world to her. She was not only a trusted colleague and valuable scientific collaborator, but a warm, cheerful, encouraging influence in our lives. We, and the thousands of patients whom she helped in her career, miss her and honor her. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her devoted family. Patrick Borgen, MD, Clifford Hudis, MD, Larry Norton, MD
docs.snippet: PETREK-Jeanne. The staff of the Evelyn H. Lauder Breast Center and the members of the Breast Diseases Management Team at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center mourn with the deepest sadness the sudden, tragic loss of our beloved colleague and friend...

docs.lead_paragraph: PETREK Jeanne. The Boards of Overseers and Managers and staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center mourn the tragic death of Jeanne A. Petrek. Dr. Petrek, a breast surgeon at Memorial Sloan-Kettering, was Director of the Surgical Program at the Evelyn H. Lauder Breast Center. Dr. Petrek first came to MSKCC as a surgical oncology fellow in 1978 and joined the medical staff in 1984, after a brief time at Emory University School of Medicine. Dr. Petrek was widely known for the care she provided to breast cancer patients, with particular focus on young women with the disease. Devoting her research efforts to the study of patient quality of life issues, she became an extraordinary advocate on their behalf. The leading expert in the United States on both lymphedema and pregnancy associated breast cancer, recognized nationally for her skills as a physician and a researcher, Jeanne Petrek was a valued and respected friend and colleague who was beloved by her many patients. She played a major role in many aspects of our organization as clinician, scientist, institutional leader, and mentor during her 23 years with the Center. Her warmth, enthusiasm, expertise, and tireless dedication to the improvement of treatment for breast cancer will be profoundly missed. We extend our sincere condolences to her husband, children, and the rest of her family. Douglas A. Warner III, Chairman Boards of Overseers and Managers Richard I. Beattie, Vice Chairman Harold Varmus, President John R. Gunn, Executive Vice President Robert E. Wittes, Physician-in-Chief Memorial Hospital

Dr. Petrek, a breast surgeon at Memorial Sloan-Kettering, was Director of the Surgical Program at the Evelyn H. Lauder Breast Center. Dr. Petrek first came to MSKCC as a surgical oncology fellow in 1978 and joined the medical staff in 1984, after a brief time at Emory University School of Medicine. Dr. Petrek was widely known for the care she provided to breast cancer patients, with particular focus on young women with the disease. Devoting her research efforts to the study of patient quality of life issues, she became an extraordinary advocate on their behalf. The leading expert in the United States on both lymphedema and pregnancy - associated breast cancer, recognized nationally for her skills as a physician and a researcher, Jeanne Petrek was a valued and respected friend and colleague who was beloved by her many patients. Her warmth, enthusiasm, expertise, and tireless dedication to the improvement of treatment for breast cancer will be profoundly missed. We extend our sincere condolences to her husband, children, and the rest of her family. Douglas A. Warner III, Chairman Boards of Overseers and Managers Richard I. Beattie, Vice Chairman Harold Varmus, President John R. Gunn, Executive Vice President Robert E. Wittes, Physician-in-Chief Memorial Hospital PETREK--Jeanne. The staff of the Evelyn H. Lauder Breast Center and the members of the Breast Diseases Management Team at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center mourn with the deepest sadness the sudden, tragic loss of our beloved colleague and friend Jeanne A. Petrek. Her presence in our lives was, and remains, a constant reminder of the highest aspirations of medicine, a calling to restore and preserve health in spirit as well as body. She was not only a superb surgeon who helped refine the current management of breast disease, but she was a tireless advocate for the quality of life of breast cancer patients, a leading researcher in topics such as lymphedema after breast surgery, pregnancy-associated breast cancer, and the preservation of fertility after treatment. Despite her international renown, she made every patient feel that she was the most important person in the world to her. She was not only a trusted colleague and valuable scientific collaborator, but a warm, cheerful, encouraging influence in our lives. We, and the thousands of patients whom she helped in her career, miss her and honor her. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her devoted family. Patrick Borgen, MD, Clifford Hudis, MD, Larry Norton, MD PETREK--Jeanne, M.D. The New York Metropolitan Breast Cancer Group, Inc., mourns the sudden and tragic loss of our long-time member, friend, colleague and teacher, Jeanne A. Petrek. Throughout her too short career she inspired us with fresh insights into the management of breast cancer and its after affects and was a cheerful and tireless advocate for patients and for the highest possible quality of care for all. Her research changed our view of this disease and held the promise of more discoveries yet to come. We will miss her always, and extend our deepest sympathies to her family. The Members and Officers of The New York Metroplitan Breast Cancer Group, Inc. Murray Seltzer, M.D., Pres. Clifford Hudis, M.D., V.P.

docs.lead_paragraph: Parliament approved a bill to allow abortion in the first four months of pregnancy if the life of the mother is in danger or if the fetus is malformed. The bill requires the consent of both parents and approval by three doctors and the coroner's office. The measure still needs approval from the watchdog Guardian Council before it can become a law. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Lawmakers Allow Abortion In Limited Cases

docs.snippet: Parliament approved a bill to allow abortion in the first four months of pregnancy if the life of the mother is in danger or if the fetus is malformed. The bill requires the consent of both parents and approval by three doctors and the coroner's...

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Jeanne Petrek, a cancer researcher known for her investigations into the aftermath of breast cancer surgery, especially its impact on fertility, was killed in an accident in Manhattan on Monday. She was 57 and lived in Bronxville, N.Y. Dr. Petrek died in surgery, hours after being struck by an ambulette while crossing the street at Second Avenue and 64th Street. At the time, she was on her way to work at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, where she directed the surgical program at the Evelyn H. Lauder Breast Center.

headline.main: Jeanne Petrek, 57, Surgeon Known for Cancer Research

docs.snippet: Dr. Jeanne Petrek, of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, was known for her investigations into the aftermath of breast cancer surgery.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Palindromes'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from A.O. Scott's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 15, 2004; the full text is online at nytimes.com/movies. This unrated film opens today in Manhattan at the Angelika Film Center, Mercer and Houston Streets, Greenwich Village, and in other theaters in New York and Los Angeles on Friday. ''Palindromes,'' the latest film by Todd Solondz, is dedicated to the memory of Dawn Wiener, the unhappy young protagonist of his second feature, ''Welcome to the Dollhouse.'' A sequel of sorts, the new movie begins at Dawn's funeral and follows the appalling adventures of her 13-year-old cousin, Aviva, for whom the dead girl serves as both inspiration and cautionary tale.

headline.main: One Role, 8 Actresses and the Worst of All Possible Worlds

docs.abstract: Excerpts from A O Scott's October 15, 2004, review of Todd Solondz movie Palindromes, which was shown as part of New York Film Festival and is opening in New York and Los Angeles (S)
docs.snippet: The real problem with the latest film by Todd Solondz is not that he goes too far, but that he seems to have no artistic interest beyond the limitless ugliness of humanity.

docs.lead_paragraph: A child whose grandmother smoked during pregnancy may have almost twice the risk of developing asthma as one whose grandmother did not smoke -- even if the child's mother was a nonsmoker, a new study has found. The study, published in the April issue of the journal Chest, is the first to show that smoking in pregnancy can harm not only a woman's children, but her grandchildren as well.

headline.main: Child's Asthma Linked To Grandmother's Habit

docs.abstract: Dr Frank D Gilliland, Keck School of Medicine preventive medicine professor, leads study that suggests risk of child developing asthma is increased when mother smokes, but also when grandmother smokes; holds that reason for findings is unclear, but link warrants more research; study, which is published in journal Chest, involved subjects participating in Southern California Children's Health Study (M)
docs.snippet: A child whose grandmother smoked during pregnancy may have almost twice the risk of developing asthma as one whose grandmother did not smoke, a new study has found.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Crossing your legs causes varicose veins. THE FACTS It's not often that an old wives' tale inspires a national movement. But in 1999, a company that makes dietary supplements started a campaign -- the ''Great American Cross-Out'' -- to stop women from crossing their legs for a day, saying the practice contributes to poor circulation and the development of varicose veins.
docs.abstract: Research shows no link between crossing legs and development of varicose veins; drawings (S)
docs.snippet: More than 12 large studies that have looked at the risk factors for varicose veins have not found leg-crossing to be one of them.
